title: Bryotropha desertella
text:
Bryotropha desertella is a <a href="moth">moth</a> of the family <a href="Gelechiidae">Gelechiidae</a>. It is found in most of Europe, <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a> (<a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>), <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, <a href="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a> and the <a href="Russian%20Far%20East">Russian Far East</a>.
The <a href="wingspan">wingspan</a> is 11–16 mm. The forewings are greyish brown to ochreous brown, mottled with fuscous. The hindwings are pale brown, but darker towards the apex. Adults have been recorded on wing from early April to late September. In the north, there probably is one generation per year. In the south, there are two generations per year.
The larvae feed on <a href="moss">moss</a>es such as "<a href="Syntrichia%20ruraliformis">Syntrichia ruraliformis</a>", "<a href="Homalothecium%20lutescens">Homalothecium lutescens</a>" and "<a href="Rhytidiadelphus%20squarrosus">Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus</a>". They can be found in autumn and spring, and have a dark reddish brown body and a shining black head. Pupation takes place in a sandy cocoon.
